item.title: Quantify post-fire impacts
item.description:
PI Siwei He
Period 2022-08 to 2023-01

First, the impact of wildfires on the land-surface biogeophysical properties, such as soil hydraulic conductivity and vegetation type, was identified and parameterized. Then, the impact of post-wildfire conditions on weather forecasting was investigated
by considering post-wildfire land-surface conditions in the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model.

item.title: Characterizing the afternoon-to-evening transition
item.description:
PI David D Turner
Period 2020-03 to 2022-07

This project aimed to improve our understanding of the complex land-atmosphere processes and their interaction during the afternoon to evening transition (AET). In particular, we proposed to use a combination of land surface and profiling observations together and mesoscale model simulations to better understand how the surface energy balance and lower atmosphere evolve during the AET.

Through this project, the performance of version 4 of the NOAA High-Resolution Rapid Refresh (HRRR) numerical weather prediction model for near-surface variables, including wind, humidity, temperature, surface latent and sensible fluxes, and longwave and shortwave radiative fluxes, was examined over the Atmospheric Radiation Measurement (ARM) Southern Great Plains (SGP) region.

This project also investigated the processes leading to the water vapor increase and the impacts of the land cover and horizontal advection on the water vapor increase through a single column model. This study also found that land cover can affect the onset of water vapor increase since different land covers may have different Bowen ratios. Water vapor increases earlier for land cover conditions that have small Bowen ratio, relative to larger Bowen ratio values.

item.title: Coupling snow sub-grid variability model into a land-surface model
item.description:
PI Siwei He
Period 2018-08 to 2020-02

This project aimed to solve the spatial variability of snow depth problem in the Earth system modeling. A snow model for representing sub-grid variability of snow depth was coupled into the Rapid Update Cycle Land Surface Model (RUC LSM), and its impacts on the LSM was evaluated.

item.title: Wyoming Center for Environmental Hydrology and Geophysics (WyCEHG)
item.description:
PI Steve Holbrook, Scott N Miller, Ginger Paige
Period 2014-09 to 2017-12

The Wyoming Center for Environmental Hydrology and Geophysics (WyCEHG) was established in July 2012 with a NSF grant. The goal of WyCEHG is to establish a center of excellence in environmental hydrology and hydrogeophysics. WyCEHG uses surface and subsurface hydrological models to link surface and groundwater.
